title: Thursday, 1st November 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Mornin'. Welcome to November.

Blank canvas morning all
Excel Developer Morninh, has the City been saved from Brexit? https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-46053283
BE11:06am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily obstacle to me getting any actual work done.

Mouselet Good morning. That article about Civl Service salaries is kind of dodgy, particularly the assumption that the kind of risk-averse person who would go into civil service rather than Google wouldn't also save 25% of post-tax income.
Flaneur @ExDev - not if they're invested in commercial property.....https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-45707529
BE11:07am

It's a day much like any other. There's a load of earnings that are either better, worse or not much different to expectations.

Soundbuy Morning - treat AV as therapy..........
Excel Developer UK PMI falls
11:07 am
BE11:08am

And there's a very tentative suggestion of a possible Brexit deal that's almost certainly a lot worse than what we already have, if it were to actually exist, which it probably doesn't.

BE11:08am

The pound rose sharply on Thursday on reports that Britain and the EU have reached an agreement on trade in financial services after Brexit, although the suggestion that a deal has been finalised was downplayed in London and Brussels.

British and EU officials have been locked in talks for months on how to ensure that the EU’s “equivalence” regime works for both sides after Brexit, given the primacy of London as Europe’s leading financial centre.

TonaldDrump up up and away
BE11:08am

British prime minister Theresa May has accepted that services — including financial services and data — would be outside the free trade area that she wants to create for goods and agriculture after Brexit in her Chequers white paper in July.

BE11:08am

https://www.ft.com...-9f04-38d397e6661c

VV75 morning

TonaldDrump colour on just eat please - low end of ebitda range but up 6%?????
Shrink Evening everyone

Look, it's not my place to give trading advice, least of all based on reports in other newspapers ... but if you're long sterling based on this you need your head sewn up.

undefined
Excel Developer 'head sewn up.' haha
BE11:14am

And onto results. First request (apart from Centamin, which is tedious) is for Just Sell.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Righty ho.

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 641.00, up 33.4 (+5.50%), High: 654.80, Low: 586.80, Volume: 3.40m
BE11:15am

So the headlines look bad. EBITDA guidance cut, yet more investment .....

Billy hi everyone
11:15 am
BE11:15am

... but those are the things we expect every report from Just Eat. What's more important is how they're trading right now.

BE11:16am

And Q3 order growth was 16% in the UK, with group organic order growth of 23%.

Grouchmonkey OK BT then. At least the market seems to think that's exciting.
BE11:16am

Everyone had anticipated that full-year guidance would be nudged lower. The positive is that the UK, maybe, has found some kind of stabilisation.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And given the shorts piling into Just Eat on the thesis of Deliveruber having deep pockets and a bigger installed userbase, that's enough to trigger the rally.

BE11:18am

Peel Hunt are still sellers, tho.

BE11:18am

Just Eat cut its EBITDA outlook (potentially -10% v CONe) and EBITDA margin (potentially -300bps v CONe) due to the impact of heavy investment in Delivery and the ‘dynamic’ LatAm markets. We cut our EBITDA again by -5%. The ‘exceptionally’ hot weather impacted Q3, but it had a strong September, which offset the impact partially. Reading into the detail of the UK Digital Services Tax plan announced this week, we believe the impact may cut Just Eat’s earnings in 2020 by 6%. Data from CGA shows that Just Eat’s biggest cuisines’ restaurants (Chinese and Indian) are suffering: over the past three years, the number of those restaurants in the UK as a whole has declined by -9% (Chinese -15%, Indian -6%). We reiterate our Sell recommendation this morning.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Chinese and Indian make up 38% of JE orders, apparently.

BE11:20am

Which is either a badge of honour for Britain's ability to integrate cultures or an indictment of its care for those cultures.

BE11:20am

Here's Barclays.

LK Hyman Shell results a bit meh?
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Nah, Barclays taking too long to open. Here's Jefferies.

BE11:21am

Putting it euphemistically, YTD has been a period of volatility for Just Eat as the market digested a downgrade cycle, a strategy pivot and a softening UK business. In that context, the Q3 out-performance and the delivery proof-points have rightly driven a relief rally. Some will seek to pillory the decision to again increase investments but in our view, Just Eat is sticking to a proven playbook and responding to an improved market structure in Brazil.

BE11:21am

The equity has suffered this year from a churn in the register and an active short interest looking to ride the downgrade cycle and squidgy messaging on the what where when why of investing in delivery. The questionable HungryHouse integration, rumours of "Uber-oo" and a hot summer in the UK (on which more below) have helped the de-rating build momentum. There is still much to be learned on delivery (and we'd urge management to disclose its impact on order frequency user acquisition as well as reinstate the profitability guidance redacted at the CMD) but in the meantime, today's news that in Canada McDonalds (this news actually broke in August; 1,400 national McDonalds units; 500 units already on Ubereats) and Tim Hortons (3,800 units; first official platform relationship) have joined Just Eat provides some comfort on execution.

Tom Dalgleish How is it an indictment?
chopper bear anything floating about on itv -
Shrink Any possibility of an indictment of British culinary failure?
11:21 am
BE11:22am

The UK did not capitulate: The stakes were high for the UK into results as the segment had been the focal point for much of the negative sentiment towards the equity (as described above). The actual performance therefore comes as a relief: UK orders of 30.3m were +1.3% ahead of consensus and equated to +15.6% yoy growth; in the process materially arresting the slow-down in growth (the UK grew +16.1% +23.8% +18.6% in the prior three quarters); indeed, Just Eat quantify the weather impact at 1-2pp implying unchanged u/l yoy growth. The commentary is upbeat too, with management calling out strong trading in September (back-to-school). Up next will be the success (or otherwise) of the launch of Skip delivery in the UK, which could / should help the "delivery break-even" narrative.

rwl Does Just Eat deserve so much coverage her? Just saying :)

And here, finally, is Barclays.

BE11:22am

After the shocking Q2/H1, we see Q3 as reassuring and the comments about a strong September shows that the summer lull was weather related and the UK should return to mid-teens organic order growth.

Grouchmonkey Re all this "Brexit deal on the horizon" stuff - well covered by FT - what is, actually, the date by which a deal HAS to be agreed for it to be implementable given the March expiry of the Art 50 notice? You would think there is an implied deadline there, that the two sides must have calculated, but what is it?
11:27 am
BE11:28am

Following a multi-year downgrade cycle that saw BT’s shares fall 60% from 500p (late 2015) to a low of 200p earlier this year, today’s Q2 results offer clear signs that the group is now firmly on an inflection path back to revenue stabilisation. This, twinned with ambitious cost cutting plans, a slowly reducing pension deficit, and normalizing capex, should support EFCF expansion from £2.4bn (Mar-19E) to £2.8bn (Mar-22E). This implies a handsome ~12% mid-term yield that would comfortably cover the current £1.5bn pa dividend. We believe this financial recovery can support a material re-rating, and as such take the opportunity to upgrade from N to OW.

BE11:28am

And Jefferies.

BE11:28am

Results ahead of expectations with hoped-for positive trends in BPS and Consumer delivered. FY EBITDA guidance raise should allay fears of new CEO 'kitchen sinking' estimates when he starts on 1 Feb.

CS1 It amazes me how the weather and Brexit has such an impact on company performance.
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Does it? Really, tho?

BE11:29am

Barclays also, since I have it open.

BE11:29am

BT 2Q EBITDA £1.87bn is +6%/£100m vs company consensus and our estimate. Of this, c50% is one-off in nature (pull forward of handset revenues in consumer, GS FX and some Openreach), but even still, Openreach/Global services showed impressive profitability trends. The guidance range has been tightened to upper range of £7.3-7.4bn as a result. On KPIs, Fixed consumer service revenues remain negative (-0.8%), with Mobile very solid (+3.8%), although Fixed churn did pick up in the quarter as a result of heightened competition. Openreach discounts only impacted 1 month of the quarter, and so will be greater in 3Q, with Consumer price increases set to offset. Elsewhere the pension deficit actually rose £700m to £5.3bn (gross of tax) due to equity market movements, and FCF was slightly below albeit working capital-related (ie temporary). On balance the EBITDA beat should be taken positively, with few obvious operational concerns.

Momentum could return thanks to an ambitious strategic plan that is to be laid out by the new CEO and prospects of more efficient use of S&N’s healthy balance sheet (M&A and/or share buyback).

BE11:43am

At first glance, the UK budget looked generally uneventful and consistent with recently stated housing policy as it mainly reaffirmed its continued support for more housing and reiterated recent initiatives along with some marginal additional policies. However, while not mentioned in his speech, the detailed documents of the budget statement included the important announcement that the government intends to extend Help to Buy for two years until April 2023 with some key adjustments: from March 2021 the new scheme will run for two more years but it will be only available for first time buyers and there will be regional price caps put in place. This extension to Help to Buy should be welcome news as it removes the uncertainty and looks supportive; particularly given the ongoing macro uncertainty around Brexit. Since its inception around 80% of Help to Buy has been used by first time buyers and the price caps look relatively generous at 1.5 times current forecast regional first time buyer prices. The extension provides more visibility out to 2023, avoids a cliff edge removal and the non-FTB use of HtoB should be able to be comfortably managed by industry and the mortgage market.

DAVID SCOTT RESPONDS TO MEDIA REPORTS REGARDING PATISSERIE VALERIE

Following recent media reports, David Scott, former shareholder and chief executive of Druckers, is keen to highlight that he has no intention to make an offer or otherwise acquire shares in Patisserie Valerie, the company that bought Druckers in 2007.

Commenting, David Scott said; "Despite the media reports, I have not appointed nor do I intend to appoint a company to liaise with shareholders on my behalf and I have no interest in making an offer for or acquiring shares in Patisserie Valerie or any related companies."

This is a statement to which Rule 2.8 of the Takeover Code applies.

ENDS

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

RBC incoming:

BE12:00pm

Our view: Whilst a headline miss, today’s Q3 financial results are a bit of a sideshow in our view considering the group already cut its FY ounce guidance with preliminary production results a few weeks back. In terms of EBITDA this was -5% miss vs. consensus and -16% vs. RBCe as gold sales lagged production. Whilst the magnitude of the miss looks large it is relatively small in absolute terms ($3 mn vs. consensus, $9 mn vs. RBCe). Disappointingly, this fed through to the group being FCF negative despite lower sustaining capex (-20% vs. RBCe) and an AISC of just $889/oz, -8% below consensus and -9% below our forecast. This is the first FCF negative quarter for CEY since 2014. Today’s results take YTD EBITDA and FCF to 62% and 67% of our FY forecasts respectively, so tracking behind even with deferred gold sales set to flow through in an operationally stronger Q4. However, the group’s cash balance of $292 mn was +11% vs. our forecast largely on the lower capex spend YTD. Given this position we still see scope for Centamin to payout a FY dividend well ahead of policy so forecast a final dividend of US5.2c taking FY dividends to US7.7c +38% ahead of consensus.

BE12:00pm

So with a dividend beat possible and a sequentially stronger Q4 expected (RBCe production +25% QoQ) why are we Sector Perform? Well post a second, surprise downgrade of FY guidance we think the lack of visibility on underground grades into 2019 and ounce volume guidance beyond this is a concern. Despite the operational issues in 2018 we would note that 2019 consensus is for production of 560koz vs. our 505koz forecast. We see significant downside risk here if underground grades come in closer to YTD 2018 run-rate of 5.5g/t or the 4.5g/t reserve grade than the market expects. Whilst this will be addressed with Q4 production results in Q1 of next year the messaging in 2018 could also mean finding “new” buyers will take a number of quarters of steady operational performance and meeting targets. This means shares could perform in line with peers into H1 2019 in our view. Due to this we continue to rate CEY Sector Perform.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Summary: Q3 EBITDA of $48.8 mn was -50%YoY, +6% QoQ but a miss vs. RBCe (-16%) and consensus (-5%). This was driven by lower gold sold (c. US$13 mn in Q3) due to the timing of final month end gold pour and the gold shipment schedule. Adjusting for this EBITDA would be +7% vs. RBCe. Q3 EPS post profit share of US0.9c/sh was -73% YoY, -30% QoQ and a miss, -19% vs. consensus, -14% vs. RBCe on the lower gold sold and on timing per the Concession Agreement with Egyptian Minerals Resources Authority (EMRA) which from July 2018 moved from a ratio of 60:40 to 55:45 CEY:EMRA. All-in Sustaining Costs (AISC) of $889/oz were -8% vs. consensus, -9% vs. RBCe as sustaining capex came in -20% lower than our forecast as FY capex guidance was reduced to US$125 mn. Looking to YTD EBITDA this now sits at 62% of our FY forecast, so tracking behind even given the deferred gold sales and likely stronger Q4 operational performance. The group was FCF negative by $1 mn due to the factors above on gold sold and profit share timing, we had forecast $8 mn of FCF generation. Previously revised FY guidance of 480koz at AISC of $875-890/oz was reiterated. Q3 production of 118koz had been pre-reported.

Blank canvas midday: thanks for everything today BE and ROTR

And Shore.

Excel Developer Howard Archer https://twitter.com/HowardArcherUK/status/1057965609508618241
BE12:01pm

Unsurprisingly, following last month’s Q3 2018 report, the Q3 2018 financials were disappointing. It was also unsurprising following those results to see yet another full-year production downgrade, this time to 480koz (from 505-515koz; originally 580koz). Total production for 9m 2018 was 334.8koz, and Centamin reported today that Q4 2018 is “on track” for 145koz.

In terms of cost guidance, AISC is now expected to be “at the top end” of the revised range of US$875-890/oz sold (originally: US$770/oz).

Alistair Wilson, Zurich’s Head of Retail Platform Strategy: “It would have been a surprise for the Bank of England to raise rates so soon after the Chancellor’s spending spree on Monday. Inflation also fell lower than expected at the last count, and wages have risen at the fastest pace in nearly a decade, easing pressure to raise rates in the immediate future. But with interest rates remaining low, and the Budget failing to provide any support for struggling savers, consumers need to consider options where they could enjoy better returns. Putting small amounts into a stocks and shares ISA or pension fund are practical ways to build a healthy sum over the years and mitigate the impact of a rise in the cost of living.”
